channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Indian Rape Victim to Be Enrolled in Boarding School
item.description: An official said the girl, 13, who was raped apparently in retaliation for something her brother did, would also be given a government job at age 18.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: American Anxieties About China Grow Slightly, Survey Finds
item.description: China’s favorable rating slipped from 37 percent to 35 percent in the past year, showing a deepening skepticism in the United States toward the country.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, right, with China's vice premier, Wang Yang, at the Strategic and Economic Dialogue in Beijing, where the unease between the two countries was on display.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ties to Edelman Subsidiary May Have Ensnared CCTV Anchor
item.description: People’s Daily posted on Twitter that that Rui Chenggang, a prominent television anchorman, held stock in a Chinese subsidiary of the public relations Edelman while the subsidiary was providing services to Mr. Rui’s employer, China Central Television.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Rui Chenggang held a 7.9 percent stake in a Chinese subsidiary of Edelman.

item.title: World Briefing: Haiti: A U.N. Cholera ‘Pilgrimage’
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations visited Haiti on Monday and sought to assure Haitians that he was committed to ending a cholera epidemic “as quickly as possible,” but he did not acknowledge his organization’s possible complicity in causing it, the subject of at least two lawsuits filed in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing : India: Court Stays Executions for 2 Convicted in Gang-Rape Case
item.description: The Supreme Court of India on Monday temporarily stayed the execution of two men convicted of raping and murdering a 23-year-old woman on a bus in New Delhi in 2012, said their lawyer, A. P. Singh, in a case that drew international attention, prompted an outcry in India and led to the strengthening of sexual assault laws in the country.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: World Briefing : Egypt: Opening for the Old Guard
item.description: An Egyptian court on Monday lifted a ban that prevented members of the political party of former President Hosni Mubarak, who was ousted in 2011, from standing in parliamentary and local elections, state media reported.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Iran Outlines Nuclear Deal; Accepts Limit
item.description: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, said Iran could accept a freeze on its capacity to produce nuclear fuel at current levels for several years, provided it could eventually produce fuel unhindered.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, accused the West of trying to sabotage a reactor being built near Arak.

item.title: Anxious Moments for an Afghanistan on the Brink
item.description: The aftermath of the presidential runoff included as tumultuous a six-day stretch for Afghanistan as any since the American invasion in 2001.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: The presidential candidates, Abdullah Abdullah, right, and Ashraf Ghani, after a pact was announced, as John Kerry looked on.

item.title: Gaza Families Near Israeli Border Struggle to Build a Life in the Heart of a Conflict
item.description: Thousands of Palestinian families have fled, some several times, during years of fighting in the Palestinian coastal territory.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Palestinian family broke its daylong fast for the observance of Ramadan at a United Nations school in Gaza City on Monday.

item.title: Sale of Paper in Venezuela Raises Fears on Freedom
item.description: Secrecy surrounds the new ownership of a leading pro-opposition newspaper, El Universal, leading some to suspect the hand of government supporters in the deal.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: El Universal’s offices in Caracas, Venezuela. The newspaper’s sale was announced this month.

item.title: William Hague Resigns as Britain’s Foreign Secretary
item.description: The resignation of William Hague was a surprise in Prime Minister David Cameron’s government shuffle.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Ukrainian Military Plane Is Shot Down as Russia Adds to Presence at Border
item.description: Although the details have yet to be verified, a spokeswoman for a separatist group said rebels had taken five members of the plane’s crew as hostages.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Wreckage of the military plane. Local residents said some of the crew members were able to jump before it crashed, but it was not known where they went.

item.title: Egypt Presents Proposal to Israel and Hamas for a Cease-Fire in Air Attacks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry was expected in Cairo on Tuesday to help advance the Egyptian truce proposal.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A man inspected what was left of an apartment building in Gaza City on Monday evening after it was struck by Israeli bombs.

item.title: U.N. Council, in Unanimous Vote, Backs Aid Delivery to Syrians in Rebel Areas
item.description: The measure permits United Nations agencies and other relief groups to deliver cross-border aid without the permission of the Syrian government.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously voted on Monday to authorize the delivery of cross-border aid to civilians in rebel-held areas without the Syrian government’s permission.

item.title: Memo From Iraq: Echoes of a Strongman in Baghdad Today
item.description: As the Iraqi government comes under relentless pressure from Sunni militants, there are echoes of the former dictator’s rule in how it has responded.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gen. Qassim Atta, the official military spokesman for the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

item.title: Open Source: Israelis Watch Bombs Drop on Gaza From Front-Row Seats
item.description: An image of Israeli spectators gathered on the high ground above Gaza to cheer the destruction below has reverberated online.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Israelis gathered on a hilltop outside the town of Sderot on Monday to watch the bombardment of Gaza.

item.title: A Focused Hunt for a Victim to Avenge Israelis’ Deaths
item.description: Officials released new details about the killing of a Palestinian youth, saying that three Israeli Jews looked for hours for a victim to avenge the killings of three Israeli teenagers.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong to Deliver Report on Electoral Reform to Beijing
item.description: In addition to reflecting Hong Kong people’s views on reform, the report may seek approval from China’s top legislative body for implementing universal suffrage in 2017.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN WONG
item.media:description: The harbor in Hong Kong, where activist groups are pushing for a broader nomination system ahead of an election for the city's top leader in 2017.

item.title: Nadine Gordimer, Novelist Who Took On Apartheid, Is Dead at 90
item.description: Ms. Gordimer found her themes in the injustices and cruelties of South Africa’s policies of racial division, and she left no quarter of the society unexplored.
item.dc:creator: By HELEN T. VERONGOS
item.media:description: Nadine Gordimer with Nelson Mandela, the former South African president, in Johannesburg in 2005.

item.title: On Soccer: Ugly Reality Intrudes On World Cup’s Glow
item.description: The 2014 World Cup was a runaway success, but significant issues like match fixing, player safety and the Cup bidding process need to be confronted.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: After a largely successful World Cup, Sepp Blatter, FIFA's president, must face criticism regarding player safety, match-fixing allegations and possible corruption in the bidding process for future Cups.

item.title: Seeding the Field: Seeking Soccer Respect, Qatar Looked Abroad
item.description: The gulf nation began an ambitious program to identify and train talented boys from Africa as it sought to build its credibility as host of the 2022 World Cup.
item.dc:creator: By STEVE EDER, SAM BORDEN, CHRISTOPHER HARRESS and JACK WILLIAMS
item.media:credit: Jason Florio for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aspire Football Dreams students receive a talk from their Spanish coach, Arseni Comas, after a match in Senegal.

item.title: Ex-Judge Leading Inquiry Into Child Abuse in Britain Steps Down
item.description: The former judge, Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, said some groups cited concerns of a conflict of interest because her brother was attorney general in the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Church of England Votes to Accept Women as Bishops
item.description: The vote by the church’s decision-making body overturns centuries of tradition and overcomes a dispute that had undermined the unity of Anglicans.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: The decision-making body of the Church of England voted on Monday to allow women to become bishops.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Samsung Contractor Suspended Over Child Labor Allegations
item.description: The cellphone maker said on Monday that it had found “evidence of suspected child labor” at Dongguan Shinyang Electronics, a South Korean-owned factory based in southern China.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Entrance to the Dongguan Shinyang Electronics factory, which makes components for Samsung mobile phones and has been accused of hiring under-age workers.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Italian Island of Elba Clings to Napoleon’s Legacy
item.description: Elba has become a microcapital of Napoleon-mania, with a full calendar of period balls, commemorative Masses, conferences, theatrical performances, book readings and walking tours.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.media:description: A re-enactment of the landing of Napoleon in Portoferraio, Elba, on May 4. Elbans say the celebrations have succeeded in pulling together the island’s different communities.
